abstract.p: The occurrence of irregular frequencies is known to affect the prediction of hydrodynamic coefficients, whether a rigid body or hydroelasticity analysis is used. For conventional ship-like structures, these irregular frequencies lie outside the range of practical interest for rigid body motions. On the other hand, for a large ship-like offshore structure, such as a Floating Production, Storage and Offloading unit (FPSO), the irregular frequencies are in the range of practical interest. Furthermore, they can create difficulties for the analysis of vessels treated as flexible bodies and of multi-hulled vessels. In these cases, distinguishing between genuine physical effects (e.g. wave interaction between hulls) and that of irregular frequencies is important.

The aim of this paper is twofold: first, elimination of irregular frequencies for the zero-forward-speed case and, second, improvement in predictions for the forward-speed case through a more accurate evaluation of the waterline integral term. Although the investigations are illustrated for rigid hulls, namely a rectangular box and a Series 60 hull, the methodology and its effects are equally valid for flexible hulls. For the zero-forward-speed case an extended boundary integral method (the lid method) is used, with the imaginary interior free surface placed approximately 0.1% below the mean free surface. It is confirmed that the lid boundary approach is an efficient and robust method for treating irregular frequencies for stationary rigid floating bodies experiencing low-frequency oscillations. For the forward-speed case a treatment of waterline integral terms is introduced, with reference to sources lying on the free surface. The applications highlight the importance of waterline integral terms which are shown to introduce oscillatory behaviour in the predicted hydrodynamic data. It is also shown that, for the forward-speed case, irregular frequencies do not occur; however, as the forward speed tends to smaller values, the hydrodynamic data exhibit oscillations which depend on the treatment of the waterline integral terms and the use of the direct potential or source distribution method. These methods are also suitable for hydroelasticity analysis with a forward speed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The occurrence of irregular frequencies in unsteady hydrodynamic analyses of ships using a boundary integral formulation causes large errors in the solution over a substantial frequency band around these frequencies. These errors cause abrupt variations in the calculated hydrodynamic coefficients, as shown by Inglis and Price,1 Wu and Price2 and Du et al.3 This is the case in all forms of surface-piercing hulls but especially when multi-hull structures are considered. For example, in a small-waterplane-area twin-hull (SWATH) type of structure, there exists the real physical phenomenon of resonant wave frequencies due to standing waves formed between the hulls, and this exhibits itself in a similar manner to irregular frequencies.4 When the two phenomena occur at closely spaced frequencies, immediate difficulties are experienced in attempting to distinguish between them.2

The zero-speed irregular-frequency problem has received much attention in the analysis of two- and three-dimensional fluid–structure interactions. The size of the frequency bandwidth effect near an irregular frequency can be reduced by increasing the number of panels discretizing the wetted hull surface; however, in practice this is not always acceptable, because it results in a substantial increase in the computational efforts required to solve the problem.5 A number of alternative numerical approaches have been developed to eliminate the effects arising from the presence of irregular frequencies. Ogilvie and Shin6 removed the first irregular frequency in a two-dimensional problem by a fundamental solution consisting of a simple wave source and a point wave source on the interior free surface acting as an absorber of the energy of the corresponding resonant Dirichlet solution. In order to remove the effects of more than the first irregular frequency, Ursell7 placed a sequence of multipole expansion-formed singularities into the simple wave source. Wu and Price2 modified and extended the Ogilvie–Shin6 asymmetric form to a modified two-dimensional Green’s function expression in a multiple-function form. Ahmed et al.8 further extended this approach for three-dimensional applications. Burton and Miller9 solved an acoustic scattering problem by generating boundary integral equations consisting of a linear superposition of the Green’s integral equation and its normal derivative with respect to the field point. As the irregular frequencies of the Green’s equation coincide with the eigenvalues of the interior Dirichlet problem, and those of its normal derivative with the eigenvalues of the interior Neumann problem, their linear combination is free of irregular frequencies if the coupling constant is complex, as discussed by Lee and Sclavounos.5 They employed this approach in surface-wave–rigid body interaction problems and they demonstrated successful removal of all irregular frequencies from the hydrodynamic coefficients. However, even though the required second derivatives of the pulsating-source Green’s function in deep water can be calculated by recurrence relations with lower-order derivatives,5 this calculation still causes a substantial discretization error.10 Yang11 overcame this difficulty by developing a non-singular form of the Green’s formula and its normal derivatives associated with the hydrodynamic exterior problems relating to three-dimensional floating bodies. The extended integral method was employed by Ohmatsu,12 who added a rigid lid onto the interior free surface to eliminate the irregular frequency associated with the interior Dirichlet eigenvalue problem. This extended integral method was further developed by Lee et al.10 In their work, the extended boundary integral equations were deduced for both the direct potential approach and the source distribution approach. In the source distribution formulation the vertical component of the imaginary fluid velocity is forced to be continuous across the body surface and is thus specified at the body–free-surface intersection from the solution of the direct potential formulation. It has been shown by many researchers (see, for example, the work by Xia et al.,13 Guilbaud et al.14 and Cheetham et al.15) that the lid method is robust and efficient.

For rigid or flexible surface-piercing ships travelling with a forward speed, unsteady hydrodynamic analyses adopting boundary integral formulations, such as translating pulsating-source methods, generate hydrodynamic data which sometimes demonstrate an oscillatory behaviour in the vicinity of irregular-frequency values associated with zero-speed (pulsating-source) methods.16,17 However, these oscillations, compared with the irregular-frequency-generated oscillations, display a different characteristic, which occupies a wider frequency range, and are much smoother in nature. Comparisons with experimental results indicate that it is not a physical phenomenon.18 Bruzzone et al.19 indicated a similar oscillation in hydrodynamic data in calculations performed for a frigate using a translating pulsating-source method.

For a rectangular box travelling with a forward speed, Du et al.3 investigated theoretically the interior Dirichlet and Neumann eigenvalue problems incorporating the linear free-surface boundary condition. A unique analytical solution describing the virtual interior velocity potential is presented. This solution is subject to imposed boundary conditions on the interior wetted surfaces of the box and on the free surface. Difficulties in solution arise when attempting to satisfy the free-surface condition involving terms dependent on the frequency of encounter ωe, the forward speed U and their combination. This frequency of the encounter–forward-speed boundary condition is complex valued in form and it is proved by two alternative approaches that the following hold.

list-item.p: To satisfy all boundary conditions the interior velocity potential is a complex-valued function with real and imaginary components each of zero value. This is not a trivial solution since it is analytically proven.
No irregular frequency exists since no condition is imposed on the frequency of encounter.
An irregular frequency exists at ωe = 0 provided that a specific speed condition is satisfied.
At zero forward speed U = 0, irregular frequencies exist.

If it is mistakenly assumed that a non-zero solution exists for the interior velocity potential by easing the form of the free-surface condition then, in the forward-speed problem, it can be shown that irregular frequencies arise but that they are fictitious.

sec.p: In points 3 and 4, a complex-valued free-surface boundary equation reduces to an equation involving real terms only and a non-zero real-valued solution of the interior velocity potential exists. (The corollary must also hold that the free-surface equations involve only real terms, e.g. the zero-forward-speed case; if it can be modified to include a complex-valued term in some way, then the resulting analysis will show no irregular frequencies.) These findings were substantiated by numerical predictions of the hydrodynamic behaviour of a rectangular box and a Series 60, CB = 0.7, hull form using the source distribution method and the direct potential method.

Now that there is proof of the absence of irregular frequencies in the ship forward-speed problem, the focus of this investigation relates to the numerical schemes of study developed to generate hydrodynamic data (at both zero speed and forward speed), the oscillatory characteristic behaviour observed in the calculated hydrodynamic data and hence the responses.

A two-dimensional extended boundary integral method to solve directly the exterior velocity potential for an oscillating cylinder advancing in the free surface was developed by Hong and Lee.20 Maury et al.21 and Guilbaud et al.14 showed that, by considering the waterline integral terms in the boundary integral equation more accurately and adding an imaginary horizontal interior surface where a zero normal-velocity condition is satisfied, the source distribution method can give smoother solutions.

In this paper, a generalised form of the extended boundary integral equation (i.e. by adding an artificial interior surface or lid), including the waterline integral term, is deduced for the direct potential method. This remains valid for the hydrodynamic analysis of ships with a zero speed or a forward speed. The form of the waterline integral terms is discussed and this new method is referred to as the improved direct potential method. The characteristics of the discrete matrix of the boundary integral equations are analysed numerically as well as the hydrodynamic coefficients for a rectangular box and a Series 60 hull form in waves with or without a forward speed. It is found that, when an extended boundary integral method is employed at a zero forward speed, the predicted irregular frequency is moved to a higher frequency as the number of panels on the interior free surface is increased, but it is not totally eliminated. To remove irregular frequencies numerically it is suggested that, in an analysis procedure using the original direct potential method and the extended boundary integral method with two or more different lid meshes, each added mass, damping coefficient or wave exciting force at any wave frequency could be selected from the average of the two closest values among these results. For the non-zero forward-speed cases, the minimum modulus of the eigenvalues of the matrices varies smoothly over a wide range of frequencies and does not tend to a zero value, as with the original direct potential method. This implies that the coefficient matrix is not ill conditioned in the calculated frequency range for all the employed methods. For a Series 60 hull form, which is of a non-wall-sided form, oscillations in the hydrodynamic data at a similar frequency to the irregular frequency for a zero-speed method are reduced when the present improved direct potential method is used in forward-speed calculations. These findings highlight the importance of the waterline integral terms in the direct potential method using a translating pulsating-source Green’s function and the validation and robustness of the lid boundary approach to eliminate irregular frequencies for a zero-speed body.

sec.title: Extended integral equations
sec.p: A numerical scheme of study is now developed for the direct potential method based on the extended integral equation (19). To avoid the singularity of the Green’s function when both the source point and the field point are on the mean free surface and close to one another, the imaginary interior free surface is shifted downwards a short distance, i.e. 0.1% of the draught of ship. Guilbaud et al.14 found that the closer the lid is to the free surface (z = 0), the greater the number of irregular frequencies that are transferred towards higher values; this results in the numerical procedure being more stable but regrettably the calculations require increased computational times. The Hess–Smith constant-panel method is employed with the composite Green’s function approach,23 in which only the port portion of the ship’s hull surface, the imaginary interior free surface and the waterline are included in the discrete boundary integral equations. The port region of the mean wetted surface of the ship hull and the interior free surface are divided into quadrilateral panels with the numbers of panels denoted by np and nf respectively, while the port region at the waterline is idealised into nl line segments. In the extended direct velocity potential approach discussed herein and expressed in equation (22), each field point is on the centre of either a hull surface or a shifted interior free-surface panel. Thus each field point is below the exterior mean free surface, which ensures that there exists no singularity in the numerical estimation of the Green’s function and its partial derivative. However, if a source point is on a waterline segment and the field point is very close to it, experience shows that a very strong oscillation with respect to the distance between these points occurs, affecting the numerical accuracy of the hydrodynamic properties when the ship translates.

sec.title: Source point lies in the mean free surface
sec.p: The behaviour of the translating pulsating-source Green’s function when a source point lies in the mean free surface is now investigated. In its general form this can be written as

It is clear that when the source point is on the waterline segment, i.e. ζ = 0, the term 1/R1−1/R2 and its first-order partial derivatives with respect to the source point in the direction of the x and y axes are zero. The afore-mentioned oscillation is thus caused by the singular behaviour of the harmonic function H(xj,ξk;−U). Figure 2 shows the non-dimensional values of the Green’s function and its partial derivatives when the source point is at (0, 0, 0) and selected field points are chosen along a segment parallel to the x axis. The length L of the segment is 1 m, and the non-dimensional values are defined as

sec.p: A sharp spike may be seen in Figure 2 when |x′|<0.02,|y′|≈0and|z′|<0.005. It is noted that the Green’s function given in equation (23) satisfies the linear free-surface condition of equation (8), which is the same as that satisfied by the radiation or diffraction velocity potential. Such a linear condition assumes that the disturbing velocity is much less than the forward speed. However, the results shown in Figure 2 for the chosen case obviously conflict with this assumption, which may cause a numerical stability problem in the hydrodynamic prediction. Fortunately, this situation usually occurs when a waterline segment (source point) is adjacent to a wetted surface panel (field point) in the direct potential method. Chen26 gave a detailed discussion of the highly oscillatory properties of unsteady ship waves and found that the wave component (the harmonic function H(xj,ξk;−U) in equation (24)) is of infinitely increasing amplitude and infinitely decreasing wavelength when z+ζ=0 but is of finite amplitude when z+ζ<0. Possible approaches to overcome this difficulty include the introduction of the integral form of the Green’s function over the panel or the downward-shifted waterline segment21 or the wave filter approach to damp higher wave-number components artificially in the Green’s function.27 In the present investigation, a nine-point Gaussian integral scheme is used to calculate the Green’s function and its partial derivatives when the distance between the waterline source point and the field point is less than three times the segment length. It is found that ignoring the line integral contribution of the Green’s function and its partial derivatives on the diagonal element in equation (22), which is equivalent to the introduction of a wave filter to remove the high wave-number components, gives smoother numerical results for a translating ship. The direct potential method with this treatment is subsequently referred to as the improved direct potential method.
To validate this numerical scheme of study, calculations of hydrodynamic data were derived for a rectangular box and a Series 60 hull form travelling at selected forward-speed values.

sec.title: Rectangular box
sec.p: Figure 3 illustrates a rectangular box of dimensions L = 1.6 m, B = 0.2 m and T = 0.1 m, with the centre of gravity in the still-water free surface. The port region of the hull surface is divided into 224 panels with four panels deep along the draught. Two different lid idealisations were examined of 128 (32 × 4) panels (lid (1)) or 288 (48 × 6) panels (lid (2)) on the port side of the interior free surface which is displaced downwards a distance of 0.1% ship draught together with 40 waterline segments. Figure 3 shows the panel distribution idealising both the external wetted surface and the imaginary interior surface of the box.

caption.p: Distribution of panels on the wetted surface and interior free surface of a box.

sec.title: Zero ship forward speed
sec.p: Irregular-frequency values were derived theoretically for this rectangular box by Du et al.3 following the procedures discussed by Inglis and Price1 and Wu and Price.2 At the calculated irregular-frequency values, the minimum modulus of the eigenvalues relating to the coefficient matrix associated with the direct potential method should theoretically approach zero. When an interior free-surface boundary is added, the coefficient matrix on the left-hand side of equation (22) should be well conditioned. To investigate this property, all the eigenvalues of the relevant matrices were evaluated with or without a lid. The minimum moduli of the eigenvalues with respect to frequency are shown in Figure 4. It is interesting to note that, when the calculated frequencies are less than the minimum irregular-frequency values of 5.2496 and 7.1098 for the port–starboard symmetric and anti-symmetric modes respectively, the minimum modulus of the eigenvalues varies smoothly with respect to frequency for the case without a lid, then decreases sharply and strongly oscillates afterwards at higher frequencies. In contrast, the lid method is expected to give an approach free of irregular frequencies. However, owing to the limited number of mesh panels dividing the interior free surface and the downward shift of the surface to avoid the singularity in the calculation of the Green’s function, the coefficient matrix remains well conditioned up to a higher value of frequency than in the original method without the lid. A similar conclusion was reached by Guilbaud et al.14 It is also found that, with an increased number of panels on the interior free surface, the transitional frequency at which the minimum modulus of the eigenvalues begins to oscillate is higher. From the numerical examples shown in Figure 4, these minimum values are transferred to non-dimensional values of 7.8 and 8.7 for the symmetric modes and to non-dimensional values of 8.9 and 10.0 for anti-symmetric modes when the interior free surface is divided into 128 panels and 288 panels, respectively.

caption.p: Minimum moduli of the eigenvalues of the coefficient matrices (rectangular box, Fn = 0.0).

sec.p: The effects of the irregular frequency on the hydrodynamic coefficients of the box are presented in Figure 5 and may be observed through the lack of smoothness in the curves. When an extended interior free surface is added, the predicted hydrodynamic coefficients vary smoothly at the original irregular frequency. However, the irregular-frequency phenomenon is still observed at higher frequencies. In the selected examples, when a 32 × 4 panel distribution on the lid is employed, the irregular frequency is observed at 7.8 for the symmetric modes, and at 8.8 and 10.8 for the anti-symmetric modes. If the distribution is increased to 48 × 4 panels, the values are 8.7 for the symmetric modes, and 10.0 and 11.7 for the anti-symmetric modes. It is noted that the numerical results obtained by different meshes coincide closely outside the narrow range centred by each irregular frequency. Furthermore, for each irregular-frequency range encountered by one particular calculation condition, the other two results agree well and vary smoothly with respect to frequency. The new terms occurring in the extended integral equation model affect the hydrodynamic behaviour only in the irregular-frequency regions.

caption.p: Added mass and damping coefficients of a rectangular box with and without lid treatments (Fn = 0.0).

sec.p: From the evidence presented in Figures 4 and 5, we have two possible options to remove irregular-frequency effects from the predictions of the hydrodynamic properties of a stationary floating body. The first is to use a refined mesh on the interior free surface to move the irregular-frequency effect beyond the range of wave frequencies of interest. This is possible if the hull is assumed to be rigid but is difficult if the hull is assumed to be flexible. The second approach is to calculate the hydrodynamic properties of a ship using all these proposed approaches for each frequency, i.e. using the original direct potential method and the extended boundary integral method with two or more different lid meshes. As demonstrated, the irregular-frequency effect does not occur with all approaches simultaneously and therefore in a pragmatic manner each added mass, damping coefficient or wave-exciting force at any wave frequency could be selected from the average of the two closest values amongst these results.

sec.title: Non-zero ship forward speed (Froude number Fn = 0.2)
sec.p: Du et al.3 examined and discussed the behaviour of the maximum modulus and the minimum modulus of the eigenvalues of the coefficient matrices evaluated by the direct potential method and the source distribution method. It was found that, regardless of whether the waterline terms are included or not, the coefficient matrix is always well conditioned over the calculated wave frequency range for both the direct potential method and the source distribution method. For a rectangular box travelling with a forward speed, no evidence of an irregular-frequency phenomenon was detected in the derived hydrodynamic coefficients. This is in marked contrast with the zero-forward-speed case although, at very low frequencies of oscillation (ωe→ 0), numerical problems were encountered which indicated an irregular frequency, thus confirming the theoretical analysis. In the numerical schemes of study, it is noted that the value of the potential or the source strength on the waterline is assumed to be equal to that on the adjacent ship hull panels. The strong variations in the Green’s function and the velocity potential near the water surface make it impossible to tackle the actual problem precisely, even if the waterline source points are no longer displaced downwards. In the improved direct potential method, we ignore the contribution of the Green’s function and its partial derivatives to the waterline integral terms when a pair of field and source points are on a surface hull panel and its adjacent waterline segment respectively. As in this situation, the amplitude of oscillation in the Green’s function and its partial derivatives with respect to the relative location between the source and field points is extremely strong, causing the numerical prediction to be unstable. Figure 6 shows comparisons of the values of the maximum modulus and the minimum modulus of the eigenvalues of the coefficient matrices by directly solving for the velocity potential around the ship hull. Four numerical methods, i.e. the original and improved direct potential methods, each with and without a lid, are involved in the comparison. It was found that a sharp variation in the value of the minimum modulus is observed at a non-dimensional frequency value of 6.6 for the improved method with an extended interior free surface (lid); the minimum modulus values are of the order of 1 for all the methods involved within the calculated encounter frequency range, and the maximum modulus values are of the order of 10.

caption.p: Maximum and minimum moduli of the coefficient matrices (rectangular box, Fn = 0.2): (a) symmetric modes; (b) anti-symmetric modes.

sec.p: Figure 7 shows a comparison of the added mass and damping coefficients calculated by these four methods. Since the coefficient matrices of the original and the improved potential methods are well conditioned, differences in the hydrodynamic coefficients predicted by the methods with or without a lid are not evident. The effect of the improved direct potential method is also not obvious for this simple wall-sided form. Both the original and the improved direct potential methods generate smooth curves of the hydrodynamic coefficients with respect to the encounter frequency, which are free of irregular frequencies. As can be seen by comparing Figures 5 and 7, the characteristic irregular-frequency blip is not evident in the speed-dependent results shown in Figure 7, and all numerical schemes produce very similar results with no influence observed if the lid is included or excluded.

caption.p: Comparisons of the hydrodynamic coefficients of a rectangular box obtained by different methods (Fn = 0.2).

sec.title: Series 60 hull form
sec.p: A realistic ship hull is adopted as a second example, namely a Series 60 model with a length of L=3.048 m, a beam of 0.436 m, a draught of 0.174 m and a block coefficient CB = 0.70.28 The mean wetted surface and the interior imaginary free surface are idealised using 576 panels and 366 panels (lid (1)) respectively, as shown in Figure 8. The interior imaginary free surface is displaced downwards by 0.1% of the ship draught.

caption.p: Distribution of panels on the wetted surface and interior free surface of a Series 60 hull with a block coefficient CB = 0.70.

sec.title: Zero ship forward speed
sec.p: The minimum moduli of the eigenvalues of the coefficient matrix on the left-hand side of equation (22) were calculated using the direct potential method with or without an interior free surface (lid (1), idealised by 366 panels). As with the rectangular box at zero forward speed, adding an interior free surface moves the irregular-frequency-affected region to higher values. For this calculation, the non-dimensional frequency translates from 4.5 to 6.9 for symmetric modes and from 6.7 to 8.3 for anti-symmetric modes, as illustrated in Figure 9. Oscillations in the predicted values are clearly seen after these non-dimensional frequencies.

caption.p: Minimum modulus of the eigenvalues of the coefficient matrices (Series 60; Fn = 0.0): (a) symmetric modes; (b) anti-symmetric modes.

sec.p: The hydrodynamic coefficients and the exciting forces were evaluated by the direct potential method with or without the imposition of an interior free surface. Comparisons of a selection of the added mass, damping coefficients and wave-exciting forces are shown in Figure 10. Irregular frequencies occur using both treatments of the interior free surface. For calculations adopting the original direct potential method without a lid, the non-dimensional irregular frequencies appearing in the ship’s hydrodynamic coefficients are at 5.2 for the symmetric modes and at 6.7 and 9.4 for the anti-symmetric modes. When a lid idealised by 366 panels (lid (1) in Figure 8) is introduced, the irregular frequencies are moved to values of 7.4 and 8.4 for the symmetric modes and the anti-symmetric modes, respectively. Adopting more refined meshes to idealise the wetted hull surface (1656 panels) and the interior free surface (724 panels, referred to as lid (2)), irregular frequencies now occur at 10.2 and 10.5 for the symmetric modes and the anti-symmetric modes, respectively. Figure 10 shows the convergence of results for these different idealisations, with at least two numerical results at each frequency being close to each other and varying smoothly around this frequency, even at an irregular frequency. This evidence confirms the numerical approach to remove the irregular-frequency effect when applied to a real ship as discussed in the section on extended integral equations for the rectangular box at Fn = 0.0.

caption.p: Added mass, damping coefficients and exciting forces on a Series 60 hull at Fn = 0.0.

sec.title: Non-zero ship forward speed
sec.p: For a Series 60 hull travelling at Fn = 0.2 the predictions of the hydrodynamic coefficients exhibit a smooth oscillation with frequency which is not present in experimental data.17,18 Du et al.29 investigated the occurrence of these oscillations and suggested that they arise from contributions to the normal derivative of the translating pulsating-source Green’s function on panels adjacent to the waterline in the vicinity of the stern region of the ship from source panels upstream, if waterline integral terms are ignored. Maury et al.21 reported that, when including the waterline integral by placing the source points on the waterline slightly displaced downwards (i.e. 10% of the immersion of the centroid of the panels adjacent to the waterline), and imposing a zero-normal-velocity condition on the interior free surface, these oscillations are removed using the source distribution method.

The hydrodynamic analysis of a Series 60 vessel travelling in waves at Fn = 0.2 was carried out using different approaches. In the original potential method, the contributions of all the waterline integral terms in equation (22) are involved. In the improved potential method, the contributions of a waterline segment on a wetted hull panel are ignored if the waterline segment is adjacent to this hull panel. In addition, the extended integral method (the lid method) was employed with different lid idealisations. For the idealisation of lid (3), the number of panels on the lid is kept the same as for lid (1), but the interior lid is shifted downwards by 2% of the ship draught, which is approximately 10% of the immersion of the centroid of the panels adjacent to the waterlines, as used by Maury et al.21 for the position of the waterline source points. For the original lid idealisation, i.e. lid (1), the downward shift distance is 0.1% of the ship draught. For comparison, selected numerical results derived by the source distribution method including the waterline integral terms are also presented. No downward displacement is assumed of the source points involved in the Green’s function and its partial derivatives in the waterline integral terms in these numerical studies.

The minimum moduli of the eigenvalues of the coefficient matrices given in equation (22) are shown in Figure 11. The minimum modulus value curves for symmetric and anti-symmetric modes vary smoothly except at the singularity point τ=ωeU/g=FnωeL/g=0.25, i.e. ωeL/g=1.25 as Fn=0.2. When potential methods without a lid were employed, the values of the minimum modulus are of the order of 1. These results clearly highlight the fact that all coefficient matrices are well conditioned. There is no irregular-frequency behaviour appearing in these numerical predictions for the forward-speed case. In contrast, strong oscillations of the minimum modulus with respect to the encounter frequency appear when the extended integral method (i.e. the lid method) is employed. The closer the lid is placed to the free surface, the stronger is the oscillatory behaviour observed. This is understandable because of the highly oscillatory properties of the translating pulsating-source Green’s function when both the field point and the source point are close to the free surface. For this case, the Green’s function and its partial derivatives cannot be evaluated accurately, as discussed by Chen and Noblesse.30

caption.p: Minimum modulii of eigenvalues of the coefficient matrices (Series 60; Fn = 0.2): (a) symmetric modes; (b) anti-symmetric modes.

sec.p: Predictions of the added mass and damping coefficients derived by the different approaches are presented in Figure 12. Since the coefficient matrix in equation (22) is not singular at the calculated frequencies, no evident difference can be detected between the numerical results obtained by the improved direct potential method and the extended boundary integral method in which the idealisation of lid (1) was employed. However, strong oscillations are observed in the non-dimensional frequency range around 5.0 for the symmetric modes and around 7.0 for the anti-symmetric modes in calculations using the source distribution method. From a non-dimensional frequency of 5.0 to higher values the numerical results obtained using the original direct potential method vary around the data derived by the present improved direct potential method. Figure 12 also shows a comparison of the calculated symmetric added mass and damping values with the heave and pitch experimental data for a Series 60 ship model measured by Gerritsma and Beukelman31 and the anti-symmetric predicted results compared with the damping and added mass experimental data measured by van Leeuwen.32 No oscillations are evident in these experimental data, which confirms that the variations in the numerically predicted hydrodynamic coefficients have no direct physical relevance and are caused by numerical procedures. It is pleasing to see that the results obtained using the improved direct potential method are in close agreement with experimental data. A similar conclusion was reached by Iwashita,33 who derived the results adopting a spline element method and showed that the direct method is preferable and that a line integral contribution should be included. A comparison with the experimental results shows that the direct potential method systematically underestimates the diagonal damping coefficients. This is probably due to the ideal fluid assumption, since the fluid viscous damping effect is excluded.

caption.p: Comparisons of the added mass and damping coefficients (Series 60; Fn = 0.2).

sec.p: Figure 13 illustrates a comparison of the predicted and the measured non-dimensional wave-exciting forces and rigid body motion responses in heave and pitch for a Series 60 hull form travelling with a forward speed (Fn = 0.2) in sinusoidal head seas. The waterline integral terms are included in the boundary integral equations of both the direct potential method and the source distribution method. For the rigid body response calculation, no viscous damping contribution is included. The experimental data for exciting forces were measured by Gerritsma.34 The experimental data for the heave and pitch motion responses were recorded by Gerritsma and Beukelman,35 in which the experimental data were measured for two different wave heights, namely 2a = L/50 and 2a = L/40, where a denotes the wave amplitude. For both the heave force and the pitch moment all numerical approaches give good agreement with one another and with the experimental data in the non-dimensional frequency range (0, 4.0). Agreement between the different numerical approaches and the experimental data is better for the heave exciting force than for the pitch exciting moment. Discrepancies between the numerical approaches are observed in the non-dimensional frequency region ωeL/g > 4.0. As with the hydrodynamic coefficient predictions, the results derived by the source distribution method exhibit stronger oscillations than observed otherwise, especially in the pitch exciting moment. For the heave and pitch responses, the numerical methods are in close agreement with one another and agree with the experimental data. The resonant frequency predicted by all the numerical methods coincides with the experimental measurements, although the magnitude of the resonant response derived by the numerical methods is overestimated because of the exclusion of viscous effects. The oscillations in both the predicted hydrodynamic coefficients and the exciting forces do not affect the rigid body responses in the cases studied.

caption.p: Exciting forces and motion responses (Series 60; Fn = 0.2).

sec.p: To validate the present improved potential method, a hydrodynamic analysis of a Series 60 hull model with a block coefficient of 0.7 was undertaken at different forward speeds. The results derived by the original and improved potential methods, the source distribution method with inclusion of the waterline integral terms, and the potential method without the waterline integral terms (denoted by WIT in Figures 15 and 16) are now discussed and subsequently presented.

The maximum and minimum modulus values of the eigenvalues of the coefficient matrix in equation (22) for different forward speeds are shown in Figure 14. Variations in these modulus predictions are found only in the low-frequency region when τ=ωeU/g=FnωeL/g<0.25, i.e. ωeL/g<1.25 as Fn=0.2. Outside this region, the minimum modulus values change slowly with respect to frequency, with values of the order of 1 and a maximum value of the order of 10 for all forward speeds. This confirms that the coefficient matrices adopted to solve the velocity potentials in forward-speed problems are always well conditioned and that the oscillations in the hydrodynamic coefficients, if they exist, do not relate to the irregular frequencies encountered in the hydrodynamic analysis of floating bodies adopting the translating pulsating-source Green’s function method.

caption.p: Maximum and minimum moduli of eigenvalues of a Series 60 hull for different forward-speed cases: (a) symmetric motions, Fn = 0.1; (b) anti-symmetric motions, Fn = 0.1; (c) symmetric motions, Fn = 0.3; (d) anti-symmetric motions, Fn = 0.3.

sec.p: The predicted added mass and damping coefficients for the Series 60 model travelling at forward speeds with Fn = 0.1 and Fn = 0.3 are shown in Figure 15 and Figure 16 respectively. The results derived by the direct potential method with or without line integral terms are presented in this figure to illustrate their respective importance. These results together with those at Fn = 0.2 show that the oscillations appearing in frequency-dependent hydrodynamic coefficients become weaker if the improved potential method is employed or when the forward speed increases. At lower speed, i.e. Fn = 0.1, it is observed that the source distribution method produces strong oscillations in the hydrodynamic coefficients near non-dimensional frequencies of 5.0 and 7.0 for the heave and sway motions respectively. These are not irregular frequencies since the corresponding eigenvalue calculations show no irregular behaviour. However, it is expected that as Fn→ 0, the results will begin to display stronger irregular-frequency characteristics, as shown in the findings for U = 0. The contribution of the line integral terms to the hydrodynamic properties of a moving ship dominates the higher-frequency region and therefore acts as pseudo-dampers in the numerical procedures. By employing the improved potential method, which artificially further damps the highly oscillating Green’s function and its partial derivatives when a waterline segment (source point) is on one side of a wetted hull panel (field point), the derived results are smoother at all the calculated frequencies. With increasing forward speed, this waterline integral contribution is also evident at lower frequency values. This is a reasonable conclusion because the line integral terms include speed effects. When the improved potential method is adopted, such oscillations exist in all the hydrodynamic coefficient curves. However, their amplitudes are suppressed, and the added mass and damping coefficients at different forward speeds tend to coincide with each other in the higher-frequency region, indicating the predictions to be increasingly speed independent.

caption.p: Added mass and damping coefficients on a Series 60 hull with a forward speed with Fn = 0.1.
Added mass and damping coefficients on a Series 60 hull with a forward speed with Fn = 0.3.

sec.p: The present improved potential method is a simplified approach to deal with the highly oscillatory properties of the frequency domain translating pulsating-source Green’s function and its partial derivatives when the source point is on the waterline segment and the field point is very close to it. Chen26 decomposed the wave component of this Green’s function into singular and highly oscillatory components, and the remaining regular component is absolutely convergent and can be evaluated in efficient numerical ways. A further study is in progress to develop a more stable and accurate potential method to analyse ship motion behaviour which is based on the present work but also includes the remaining regular component of the Green’s function analytically expressed by Chen.26

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An extended boundary integral formulation is developed to calculate the radiation and diffraction velocity potentials associated with ships travelling with a forward speed. It is theoretically proved that, when an artificial interior surface (lid) is added and satisfies the zero-potential condition on all the enclosed surfaces, the interior Dirichlet problem has an unique zero-valued solution; the corresponding discrete coefficient matrix is therefore well conditioned. The exterior velocity potential can be solved using equation (19) or its discrete form expressed in equation (22). The solution is free of irregular frequencies.

When the source point is on the true waterline segment, the translating pulsating-source Green’s function and its partial derivatives vary strongly when a field point is close to a source point. Usually this happens in a discrete numerical prediction when the field point is at the centre of a panel adjacent to the free surface. In the present study, a nine-point Gaussian integral scheme is used to calculate the Green’s function and its partial derivatives when the distance between the waterline source point and the field point is less than three times the waterline segment length. In particular, when the source point is on one edge of a wetted hull panel, the Green’s function and its partial derivatives are set to zero, which equates to the introduction of a wave filter to remove the high-wave-number components for this special case only. Numerical calculations show that weakly oscillating results are achieved for the hydrodynamic analysis of travelling ships by this treatment.

Numerical predictions of the hydrodynamic behaviour of a rectangular box and a Series 60 hull form at zero speed demonstrate the existence of irregular frequencies, which appear first at low frequency values and at higher frequencies within the calculated frequency region. Irregular frequencies remain present in the results derived by the lid method but are now shifted to higher frequency values than in the original results without a lid. The occurrence of the irregular frequency is also sensitive to the mesh density and distribution on the lid. On the basis of these findings, two practical approaches are suggested to remove the irregular-frequency effects using the extended integral method.

For a ship travelling with a forward speed (i.e. a rectangular box and Series 60 hull form), no evidence is found for the existence of irregular frequencies in the discrete numerical hydrodynamic predictions by either the source distribution method or the direct potential method. This reaffirms the theoretical analysis of Du et al.3 The numerical results for the minimum modulus of the eigenvalues of the coefficient matrices to solve for the velocity potentials vary smoothly if τ = ωeU/g > 0.25 and are always of the order of 1. The oscillation appearing in the predicted values of the hydrodynamic coefficients and the exciting forces are figments of the numerical procedures relating to the treatment of the line integral terms in the boundary integral equations. The extended integral method, which is valid for the zero-speed case to remove irregular-frequency effects, is redundant for the forward speed cases. From numerical calculations, it is found that using the direct potential method instead of the source distribution method can suppress these oscillations, especially when the waterline integral terms are properly treated, as discussed in this investigation.

The present authors believe that it is difficult to apply the extended integral method to the hydroelasticity analysis with a zero forward speed. For this particular case, the second approach of using two or more lid settings may be necessary, as discussed in the section on the rectangular box. However, for the non-zero forward-speed case, the methods illustrated and applied in this paper are suitable for inclusion when a flexible vessel is considered.
